sentence: At first glance, it doesn't look good: Shares of Home Depot Inc ( HD ) fell after the home improvement retailer announced that same-store sales slowed towards the end of the first quarter.
Does this pullback signal the end of Home Depot's impressive run, or is this a buying opportunity?
In my opinion, it's the latter case.
For starters, Home Depot's first-quarter report was quite strong otherwise.
For the quarter, Home Depot posted earnings of $1.8 billion, or $1.44 per share, on $22.8 billion in sale.
Compared with the year ago quarter, this represented 12.5% bottom-line growth and 9% top-line growth.
Analysts were looking for $1.36 EPS on $22.39 billion in revenue, so Home Depot posted a 5.9% earnings surprise and a 1.8% sales surprise.
Second, for the first quarter Home Depot exceeded analysts' same-store sales growth expectations.
Sales at stores open a year or longer rose 7.4%, well above the 4.9% consensus estimate.
Most importantly, Home Depot also lifted its FY 2016 outlook.
The company is now targeting 4.9% same-store sales growth, above its previous range of 3.7% to 4.5% growth.
Home Depot is also aiming for $6.27 EPS, above its previous forecast of $6.12 to $6.18 EPS.
In my opinion, April's results were a blip on the radar, and Home Depot will continue to see robust sales and earnings growth through year-end.
The stock is still trading at a reasonable valuation, especially considering its $18 billion stock buyback program and 2% annual dividend yield.
HD is also one of my rare "double A" stocks, in that it earns top marks in both Portfolio Grader and Dividend Grader .
So if you're looking to add HD, today's pullback presents an excellent buying opportunity.
